title: Increasing User Retention Through a Smarter Onboarding Experience
subtitle: Updating Viata's onboarding form to support customization and reduce drop-off

infoTable.label: My Role
infoTable.value: Entire product design from research to conception, visualization and testing (OR Research, Wireframing, Interface Design, Development)

content.text: Viata is a travel tech startup that helps event organizers create interactive maps for their events. These maps highlight venues, hotels, and local attractions to help attendees explore and navigate their surroundings.

A key part of this process is the onboarding form — a multi-step flow that guides organizers through customizing their event map by selecting locations and tailoring details to their event. I was tasked with redesigning this form with the broad goal of improving usability and aesthetics
It was up to me to identify key usability issues, clarify the form's purpose, and propose design solutions that would align with the evolving product vision.
Several real-world limitations shaped my approach to the redesign:

cards.label: Constraint #1
cards.title: Tight Timelines
cards.body: The onboarding form needed to be updated in time for a product launch just four weeks away. This meant the scope had to stay focused and decisions had to be made quickly.

cards.label: Constraint #2
cards.title: Startup Realities
cards.body: With limited team size, budget, and access to users, research and testing had to be creative and scrappy.

cards.label: Constraint #3
cards.title: No Design Mentor
cards.body: As the only designer on a small team, I had no dedicated design mentor. I navigated the UX process independently — framing the problem, conducting research, exploring solutions, and collaborating directly with developers.

content.text: Given limited time and access to users, I used a combination of direct and indirect research methods to understand usability issues and opportunities within the onboarding form:

cards.label: Method #1
cards.title: Heuristic Evaluation
cards.body: I conducted a thorough Heuristic Evaluation of the onboarding form, applying [Jakob Nielsen's heuristics](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/) to identify issues related to consistency, feedback, navigation, and error prevention.

cards.label: Method #2
cards.title: User Feedback
cards.body: I drew on insights from my manager's conversations with event organizers, which revealed requests for more customization and additional features in the onboarding form.

cards.label: Method #3
cards.title: Best Practices Research
cards.body: I reviewed onboarding best practices from leading companies via [Growth.Design case studies](https://growth.design/case-studies) to identify patterns that improve clarity, engagement, and retention.

cards.label: Method #4
cards.title: Session Replays
cards.body: I analyzed user session recordings to observe behavior during onboarding. While this helped identify where users hesitated or struggled, it didn't provide insight into why they behaved that way, limiting its impact on uncovering root causes.

content.text: My research revealed key insights about the onboarding form:

cards.label: Finding #1
cards.title: Users Desired More Customization
cards.body: Event organizers wanted greater control over their maps, including options to customize hotels and map appearance.

cards.label: Finding #2
cards.title: Inconsistent Design Patterns Across Steps
cards.body: The form's interface behaved differently depending on the type of location, leading to confusion and a fragmented experience.

cards.label: Finding #3
cards.title: Aesthetic Shortcomings
cards.body: The form's visual design felt outdated and didn't align with the product's vision for a modern, engaging experience.

content.text: Below is a walkthrough of the original onboarding form. I've annotated the screenshots to highlight usability issues and pain points uncovered during research.

Before jumping into high-fidelity design, I explored wireframes to experiment with structure, flow, and layout. At this stage, my goal wasn't to lock in detailed solutions — but to test ways the onboarding form could better support added features, improve clarity, and feel more cohesive.

These wireframes explored ways to better organize the form and prepare it for new features like hotel customization and live map previews. They also revealed key challenges around simplifying and unifying the user experience that guided the prototyping phase. Based on these insights, I defined the key design challenges to focus on in the next phase:

cards.label: Challenge #1
cards.title: Customization vs. Complexity
cards.body: Giving users more control without overwhelming them is challenging, especially in the hotels step, where too many options can confuse rather than help.

cards.label: Challenge #2
cards.title: Consistency Across Steps
cards.body: Different location types require different behaviors, but inconsistent patterns across steps can confuse users and break the unified experience.

cards.label: Challenge #3
cards.title: Clarity and Navigation
cards.body: Users need clear guidance on where they are in the process and how to move forward or back, ensuring smooth navigation throughout the flow.
